candidates.title: Old Photo Shows Obama, Fauci at U.S. Facility
candidates.content:
Quick Take
An image circulating on social media claims to show former President Barack Obama, Dr. Anthony Fauci and Melinda Gates at the Wuhan lab in 2015. The photo was actually taken at the National Institutes of Health campus in Maryland  and Melinda Gates is not in the picture.
Full Story
A years-old photo of former President Barack Obama and Dr. Anthony Fauci is spreading on Facebook with a false claim to suggest a connection to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Dr. Fauci, Melinda Gates and Barack Obama at the Wuhan Lab in 2015!!!! reads text at the top of the viral image.
Below it, a screenshot of a tweet shows a photo of Obama speaking with a scientist as Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, stands in the background alongside a woman misidentified as Melinda Gates.
The tweets text claims that the picture shows Fauci who was with Obama in 2015 in the WuHan lab where they paid the lab 3.7 million for a bat project? We know that well now right? He is of the deep state you get instructions from him. Cut the crap! All to take Trump down!
But the photo is not from the Wuhan lab; the tweet distorts the facts regarding federal funds and the Wuhan Institute of Virology; and the image does not show Gates.
A reverse image search of the picture showed the photo originated on a blog run by the National Institutes of Health. The post shows that the photo was taken in December 2014  in the U.S.
The picture captured Obama touring the NIH Vaccine Research Center at the NIH campus in Bethesda, Maryland.
Obama was speaking with Dr. Nancy Sullivan, of NIAID, about Ebola research. And Fauci was speaking with former Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia Burwell  not Melinda Gates.
The tweets claim that they paid the lab 3.7 million for a bat project, meanwhile, is a repeat of a distortion that weve addressed multiple times before.
That figure refers to an NIH grant  which actually totaled $3.4 million  awarded to EcoHealth Alliance, a U.S.-based research group that was studying the risk of future emergence of coronaviruses from bats.
The organization first received the grant in 2014 and the grant was renewed in 2019 for another five years, EcoHealths spokesman, Robert Kessler, told us previously. EcoHealth received $292,161 in 2019 (part of the total $3.4 million that it received) and NIH terminated the grant in April.
EcoHealth worked with the Wuhan Institute of Virology  a collaborator approved by the State Department and NIH  but the lab received only $600,000 of the grant over the years, Kessler said in May.
Editors note: FactCheck.org is one of several organizations working with Facebook to debunk misinformation shared on social media. Our previous stories can be found here.
Sources
Collins, Francis. Presidents Visit to NIH Highlights Research on Ebola. NIH Directors Blog. 2 Dec 2014.
Fichera, Angelo. Facebook Post Repeats Flawed Claim on Wuhan Lab Funding. FactCheck.org. 17 Jun 2020.
Kessler, Robert. Spokesman, EcoHealth Alliance. Email to FactCheck.org. 8 May 2020.
National Institutes of Health. Project Information | 2R01AI110964-06. Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools. Accessed 15 Jul 2020.
Regarding NIH Termination of Coronavirus Research Funding. Press release, EcoHealth Alliance. 28 Apr 2020.
Robertson, Lori. Trump Spreads Distorted Claim on Wuhan Lab Funding. FactCheck.org. 15 May 2020.
candidates.description: An image circulating on social media claims to show former President Barack Obama, Dr. Anthony Fauci and Melinda Gates at the "Wuhan lab in 2015." The photo was actually taken at the National Institutes of Health campus in Maryland -- and Melinda Gates is not in the picture.

candidates.title: Photo does not show Obama at a lab in Wuhan, China, in 2015
candidates.content:
CLAIM: Photo shows Dr. Anthony Fauci, Melinda Gates and Barack Obama at the Wuhan lab in 2015.
APS ASSESSMENT: False. The photo shows then-President Barack Obama visiting the National Institutes of Health in 2014 along with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nations top infectious disease expert, and then-Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell. They are listening to Dr. Nancy Sullivan, chief of the Biodefense Research Section of The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
THE FACTS: A post circulating on Facebook falsely claims the former president visited an infectious disease lab in Wuhan, China, in 2015, an effort to link Obama to a debunked conspiracy theory that the coronavirus was made in a lab.
The post includes a screenshot of a tweet with the photo that says, you mean this Dr. Fauci who was with Obama in 2015 in the Wuhan lab where they paid $3.7 million for a bat project.
The photo not only does not show Obama in Wuhan, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, but it also inaccurately portrays Obamas role with the grant. In 2014, the National Institutes of Health awarded EcoHealth Alliance, a New York-based environmental health nonprofit, a grant of $3.25 million for five years to study bats in southern China for unknown coronaviruses. The Wuhan Institute of Virology received about $600,000 of the grant. The grant was renewed under President Donald Trumps administration in 2019, but was terminated in April before new funding could be given to the Wuhan Institute of Virology.
The photo of the president at the NIH campus in December of 2014 can be found on the NIH directors blog with the accurate caption. Obama visited the NIH Vaccine Research Center to see work being done against Ebola. During his visit, he also gave a speech where, the blog says, he emphasized the need for emergency congressional authorization of resources for Ebola research.
___
This is part of The Associated Press ongoing effort to fact-check misinformation that is shared widely online, including work with Facebook to identify and reduce the circulation of false stories on the platform.
Heres more information on Facebooks fact-checking program: https://www.facebook.com/help/1952307158131536
candidates.description: A post circulating on Facebook falsely claims the former president visited an infectious disease lab in Wuhan, China, in 2015, an effort to link Obama to a debunked conspiracy theory that the coronavirus was made in a lab.

candidates.title: Is This Obama, Fauci, and Gates at a Wuhan Lab in 2015?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows President Obama, Dr. Anthony Fauci, and Melinda Gates at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, in 2015.
In July 2020, a photograph supposedly showing then-U.S. President Barack Obama, Dr. Anthony Fauci, and Melinda Gates at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, in 2015 started to circulate on social media:
This is a genuine photograph of Obama and Fauci  but it was not taken in Wuhan, China, in 2015. Also, the woman in the red shirt is not Melinda Gates.
This photograph was taken in December 2014 at the Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland, and shows Obama and Fauci with U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Sylvia Burwell and Chief of the Biodefense Research Section Nancy Sullivan.
The photograph is available via the NIH Director's blog, where it is accompanied by the following caption: "Dr. Nancy Sullivan of NIHs National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) discussing Ebola research with President Barack Obama as NIAID Director Dr. Anthony Fauci and HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell look on."
Dr. Francis Collins went on to write in the blog:
Today, we had the great honor of welcoming President Barack Obama to the campus of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, MDto see first-hand the progress that biomedical research is making against Ebola virus disease. The President toured the NIH Vaccine Research Center, and met with scientists who are working hard to develop ways to combat this deadly virus that continues to devastate West Africa. And, in a speech before a packed auditorium at the NIH Clinical Center, the President praised the contributions of NIH staff. He also emphasized the need for emergency Congressional authorization of resources to ensure that our nations research and public health efforts against Ebola will lead as quickly as possible to an end to this devastating outbreak.
A number of similar images from this visit are available via Getty Images.
The text accompanying this viral image also full of misinformation. We addressed this alleged grant to a laboratory in Wuhan, China, more in depth in this article.
candidates.description: What's a conspiracy theory without miscaptioned illustrations?

result.explanation: The news caption is False.  All three sources explicitly state that the photo was taken at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland in December 2014, not at a Wuhan laboratory in 2015.  The sources also clarify that Melinda Gates was not present in the photograph.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: "The photo was actually taken at the National Institutes of Health campus in Maryland -- and Melinda Gates is not in the picture." Source 2: "The photo shows then-President Barack Obama visiting the National Institutes of Health in 2014 along with Dr. Anthony Fauci...They are listening to Dr. Nancy Sullivan...The photo not only does not show Obama in Wuhan...but it also inaccurately portrays Obama's role with the grant." Source 3: "This is a genuine photograph of Obama and Fauci -- but it was not taken in Wuhan, China, in 2015. Also, the woman in the red shirt is not Melinda Gates. This photograph was taken in December 2014 at the Vaccine Research Center at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland"

final_result.explanation:
The original caption claims that the photograph depicts President Obama, Dr. Anthony Fauci, and Melinda Gates at a laboratory in Wuhan, China, in 2015.  Both internal and external validation checks strongly refute this claim. 

Internal Validation:
The internal check expresses low confidence (confidence score of 7) due to uncertainties about the identities of the individuals other than Obama and the inability to verify the location and year from the image itself.  While Obama's presence is confirmed, the identification of the other individuals as Fauci and Gates, and the assertion about the Wuhan laboratory in 2015, rely solely on the caption's assertion and cannot be verified internally.

External Validation:
The external check decisively contradicts the caption with a high confidence score of 10.  It cites three sources that explicitly state that the photo was taken at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, Maryland, in December 2014, not Wuhan in 2015.  These sources also clarify that Melinda Gates was not present in the photograph.  The consensus among these three sources strongly undermines the claim in the original caption.

Discrepancies and Conflicts:
There is a clear and significant conflict between the internal and external validation checks. The internal check expresses uncertainty due to the limitations of image analysis alone, while the external check provides strong evidence from multiple sources to show the original caption is inaccurate. 

Resolution:
Given the high confidence (score of 10) of the external validation based on three consistent sources and the lack of strong supporting evidence from the image itself (low confidence score of 7 for internal validation), the external evidence carries more weight.  The discrepancies are resolved by prioritizing the externally validated information.  The caption is definitively out of context because it misidentifies the location, the year, and one of the individuals in the photograph.

Entity Analysis:
Entity analysis supports the external validation results.  The external sources provide specific verifiable details (location, year, participants) that are directly contradicted by the original caption's claims.  The image itself, without additional contextual information, only supports the presence of President Obama; other individuals cannot be definitively identified based solely on the image.

Conclusion:
The original caption is definitively out of context (OOC = True).  The high confidence score (10) reflects the overwhelming evidence from three independent external sources that directly contradict the caption's claims.  The uncertainty expressed by the internal check is significantly outweighed by the strong external evidence.  The discrepancies between internal and external checks are resolved by prioritizing the robust, consistent external evidence.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation checks strongly indicate that the original caption is inaccurate.  Internal validation expresses uncertainty due to image limitations, while external validation, with high confidence, uses multiple sources to show that the caption misrepresents the location, date, and individuals in the photograph.  The caption is definitively out of context.

results.caption: Pastor Rick Scarborough attributed the cause of breast cancer to impure fantasies

result.explanation: The image shows Rick Scarborough, and the caption accurately reflects that.

There is no scientific evidence supporting the claim that impure fantasies cause breast cancer.  Attributing a complex disease like breast cancer to such a factor is a significant departure from established medical understanding. This statement reflects a misconception and a lack of understanding of the scientific consensus on breast cancer etiology.
result.supporting_points: Breast cancer is a complex disease with multiple risk factors, including genetic predisposition, hormonal factors, lifestyle choices, and environmental exposures.  There is no scientific basis to link it to 'impure fantasies'.

final_result.explanation: The internal check shows high confidence that the image depicts Rick Scarborough and that the caption aligns with the context of a statement attributed to him. However, the external check reveals a significant discrepancy. The external check, with high confidence, refutes the claim made in the caption—that impure fantasies cause breast cancer—citing the lack of scientific evidence. This conflict necessitates a careful analysis of the evidence. The internal check's high confidence stems from a simple image-caption alignment, while the external check's high confidence is based on established scientific knowledge concerning the etiology of breast cancer. The strong external evidence against the caption's claim outweighs the internal check's simple verification of the image-caption alignment.  The claim that impure fantasies cause breast cancer is factually incorrect and scientifically unsupported.  Therefore, based on the combined analysis of both internal and external checks, the caption is deemed out of context because the statement attributed to Rick Scarborough lacks scientific validity. The consensus of medical and scientific understanding overwhelmingly refutes such a claim. Any association between a complex disease like breast cancer and subjective concepts like "impure fantasies" is not grounded in reliable evidence. In conclusion, while the image correctly identifies Rick Scarborough, the caption misrepresents his statement's scientific accuracy and thus is deemed out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal check confirms image-caption alignment, but external check strongly refutes the claim's scientific validity. The external evidence outweighs the internal alignment, leading to an out-of-context conclusion.

results.caption: Editorial picture of Tunisian Harissa being prepared in Tunis, Al Maamoura, Tunisia - 27 Nov 2020

result.explanation: The image shows the preparation of Harissa, a Tunisian sauce. The location is not explicitly shown but the context suggests Tunisia. The entities are mostly correct, although "Hari" and "##ssa" might be better represented as a single entity "Harissa". The location details are not visually confirmed.

Tunisian Harissa is a dish that originates from Tunisia, so it is plausible that a picture of it being prepared in Tunis exists.  The date (November 27, 2020) is a specific date within a reasonable timeframe. The location, Al Maamoura, is a suburb of Tunis, which also adds to the plausibility. However, without seeing the image itself, I cannot definitively confirm its existence or accuracy. There's no readily available information online to verify the existence of this specific photo.
result.supporting_points: Tunisian Harissa is a real dish from Tunisia; Al Maamoura is a suburb of Tunis; November 27, 2020, is a valid date.

final_result.explanation:
The internal and external validation checks both agree that the caption is likely accurate.  The internal check highlights the strong alignment between the image content (ingredients for Harissa, a Tunisian sauce) and the caption's description. The only minor discrepancy noted was the suggestion of representing "Hari" and "##ssa" as a single entity "Harissa." This is more of a stylistic suggestion rather than a factual inaccuracy. The external check reinforces this by confirming Harissa's origin in Tunisia, making the location mentioned in the caption plausible.  Both checks correctly point out the lack of explicit visual confirmation of the location in the image, which does not diminish the general plausibility of the caption given the context. 

The confidence score of 8 reflects the high degree of agreement between the two checks while acknowledging the lack of direct visual evidence for the specific location details in the image. The external check notes the plausible, yet unverifiable, date and location. While the date and location are not directly confirmed by the visual content, the nature of the food preparation depicted aligns strongly with the caption's description and the cultural context of Harissa in Tunisia.

External validation supports the general accuracy of the caption by confirming the existence of Harissa and its Tunisian origin, and by finding no reason to doubt the plausibility of the specified date and location. The external check appropriately qualifies its confidence by stating it cannot definitively confirm the photo's existence without actually seeing it. This aligns with the conservative approach advocated in the validation instructions.

In summary, while the image itself does not definitively prove the precise location or date, the strong internal consistency and supporting external validation related to the food depicted provide a high degree of confidence in the caption's overall accuracy.  The lack of direct visual confirmation for the precise date and location is the primary reason the confidence score remains below a perfect 10. Any speculative statements concerning details not visibly supported by the image have been avoided, in line with the guidelines.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks support the caption's accuracy, with high confidence. The main limitation is the lack of visual confirmation of the precise location and date in the image, but the overall context makes the claim highly plausible.

results.caption: Is This Kim Jong Un Reading Fire And Fury

result.explanation: The image clearly shows Kim Jong Un reading a book titled "Fire and Fury".  All entities are correctly identified and their relationship in the image is accurate.

candidates.title: Is This Kim Jong-Un Reading 'Fire and Fury'?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows North Korea leader Kim Jong-un laughing as he reads the book Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House.
Rating:
False
About this rating
It isn't hard to imagine North Korea leader Kim Jong Un  who once referred to U.S. President Donald Trump as a "mentally deranged U.S. dotard"  delighting in the release of the book Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House. The book describes a commander-in-chief sliding into dementia, surrounded by a staff that does not respect him.
So in January 2018, when an image purportedly showing Kim Jong Un reading the Michael Wolff book and laughing, some people were understandably fooled:
This image was created by cropping a photograph of Kim to focus in on his face and then digitally adding an image of Fire and Fury. The real picture was taken in 2015, and showed the North Korean leader at a Pyongyang laver processing factory.
Here's a look at the original photograph, as well as a side-by-side comparison of a cropped version of the original picture (bottom left) and the doctored image featuring Fire and Fury (bottom right):
candidates.description: A doctored image purportedly shows the North Korean leader reading a book that portrays U.S. President Donald Trump and his staff in an unflattering light.

result.explanation: The provided evidence from Snopes explicitly debunks the claim that the image of Kim Jong-un reading "Fire and Fury" is genuine.  Snopes demonstrates that the image is a doctored photograph, with the book digitally added. Therefore, the news caption is false.
result.supporting_points: Snopes' fact-check explicitly states that the image of Kim Jong-un reading "Fire and Fury" is digitally altered. The original photograph shows Kim Jong-un in a different setting, and the book was added later.

final_result.explanation: The internal validation check gives a high confidence score (10) that the caption accurately reflects the image content.  The image depicts Kim Jong Un seemingly reading "Fire and Fury." However, the external validation check, using Snopes as a source, strongly contradicts this with a confidence score of 10. Snopes definitively states the image is digitally altered; the book was added to the original photo. This creates a direct conflict.  Given the high confidence score from both checks, and the strong evidence from the reputable fact-checking website Snopes, the image is determined to be misrepresented. The caption, therefore, is out of context because it presents a fabricated image as genuine evidence. The digitally altered nature of the image invalidates the caption's claim. There's no ambiguity; the image is manipulated. Therefore, concluding that the caption is out of context is justified with high confidence.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal validation confirms the caption matches the image content. However, external validation (Snopes) proves the image is digitally manipulated, making the caption out of context.

results.caption: Televangelist Joel Osteen endorsed Donald Trump.

result.explanation: The image shows Joel Osteen.  The caption mentions that he endorsed Donald Trump, but the image itself does not provide any evidence of this endorsement. The image only shows Joel Osteen; there is no mention of Donald Trump in the image.

candidates.title: Joel Osteen Endorses Donald Trump
candidates.content:
Claim:
Televangelist Joel Osteen endorsed Donald Trump.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 7 October 2015, televangelist Joel Osteen made an appearance on the Kilmeade And Friendsradio show, during which Osteen said that he understood Trump's "make our country great again" message:
I think [the message] resonates to, Hey, maybe the country is not where it should be. Lets get back to where we were. Like you said, Mr. Trump is an incredible communicator and brander, like Mr. Clinton said. Hes been a friend of our ministry. Hes a good man.
Several months after Osteen's appearance on the Kilmeade and Friends show, his comments began to recirculate under misleading headlines which insinuated that that Osteen had officially endorsed Trump for president. For example, entertainment web site Evenin-Tea.com published a video of Osteen's comments under the title "Guess Whos Endorsing Trump, Joel Freaking Osteen  You Done Yet? This Latest Trump Endorsement Is Gonna Rock Some Worlds."
While Osteen's admiring comments fell far short of an actual endorsement, the televangelist still found it necessary to clarify his political position. In March 2016, his church released a statement:
Contrary to the misinformation currently making the rounds on social media, Pastor Joel Osteen has not endorsed any candidate for President of the United States.
Preacher and televangelist Joel Osteen is the pastor at Houston-based Lakewood Church, the one of the largest in the United States.
candidates.description: While Joel Osteen complimented Donald Trump during a radio interview, he did not endorse him for president.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes explicitly states that Joel Osteen did not endorse Donald Trump, despite circulating misinformation suggesting otherwise.  Osteen's comments were complimentary but did not constitute an endorsement.  Snopes cites Osteen's church statement denying an endorsement as evidence.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check directly refutes the claim.  It states, "Contrary to the misinformation currently making the rounds on social media, Pastor Joel Osteen has not endorsed any candidate for President of the United States."

final_result.explanation: The internal check analyzes the image and caption for consistency. The image shows Joel Osteen, but the caption claims he endorsed Donald Trump.  The image itself provides no evidence of such an endorsement.  The internal check thus concludes the caption is likely out of context, with a confidence score of 10. The external check corroborates this by citing a Snopes fact-check that directly refutes the claim of Osteen endorsing Trump. Snopes provides evidence that Osteen has denied such an endorsement, and that statements attributed to him were complimentary but did not constitute an endorsement. The external check also reaches a conclusion that the caption is out of context, assigning a confidence score of 8.  Both internal and external checks strongly agree that the caption is out of context. The discrepancy in confidence scores (10 vs 8) is minor, and both are high. This convergence significantly strengthens the conclusion. There is no conflict or uncertainty; both checks support the same conclusion using different methods. The entity analysis aligns with both checks as it confirms the presence of Joel Osteen in the image and the absence of any explicit evidence of an endorsement of Donald Trump. Given the high confidence scores and complete agreement between both validation methods, the final confidence score is 9. In summary, the caption is clearly out of context because it asserts a fact not supported by the image or reliable external sources.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks independently and strongly agree that the caption 'Televangelist Joel Osteen endorsed Donald Trump' is out of context. The image shows only Joel Osteen and contains no evidence of an endorsement.  External verification confirms that credible sources refute the claim of endorsement.

The caption's claim that the photo proves Trump was lying about not knowing her is an interpretation of the visual evidence, not a direct visual fact. candidates.title: Does This Photo Show Trump With E. Jean Carroll?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A viral photograph shows Donald Trump with E. Jean Carroll, who's accused him of past sexual assault, proving he was lying when he said he didn't know her.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
On 25 June 2019, social media users shared an image of Jill Harth, a woman who has accused Donald Trump of groping her, apparently confusing her with E. Jean Carroll, yet another woman who accused the incumbent U.S. president of past sexual assault:
This is a picture of Harth, not Carroll, although some users shared it with the erroneous belief that it undermined Trump's claim that he didn't know Carroll. Carroll has accused him of raping her in a Bergdorf Goodman fitting room in the mid-1990s.
In an interview with The Hill, Trump said the incident never happened, stating that Carroll was "not my type."
"I don't know anything about her," Trump declared. "I know nothing about this woman. I know nothing about her. She is -- it's just a terrible thing that people can make statements like that."
(New York magazine and other mainstream news outlets published a different photograph showing Trump in the company of Carroll, her then-husband John Johnson, and Trump's then-wife Ivana at a public event in the 1980s. Trump didn't question the authenticity of that photograph but continued to insist, in spite of it, that he had "absolutely no idea" who E. Jean Carroll was.)
The image of Harth with Trump was taken more than 20 years earlier. Harth accused Trump of having groped her in 1992 in his daughter's bedroom. The picture was published during a 2016 broadcast of the TV news show Inside Edition, in a story about Harth's allegations. It can be viewed at about the 45-second mark in the video below:
candidates.description: Social media posts have confused one woman who has accused Trump of sexual assault with another accuser.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes directly addresses the claim in the news caption.  While a photo of Trump with E. Jean Carroll exists (from a different source not included here), the viral photo in question is actually of Jill Harth, another accuser.  The Snopes article explicitly states that the viral image was miscaptioned and used erroneously to suggest Trump was lying about not knowing Carroll.  Therefore, the caption's claim is false.
result.supporting_points:
Claim: A viral photograph shows Donald Trump with E. Jean Carroll, who's accused him of past sexual assault, proving he was lying when he said he didn't know her.
Rating: Miscaptioned
...This is a picture of Harth, not Carroll, although some users shared it with the erroneous belief that it undermined Trump's claim that he didn't know Carroll.

final_result.explanation: The internal check shows some confidence in the caption's claim, scoring it as true with a confidence of 10. However, this is primarily based on the image showing Trump and a woman, and interpreting this as proof of Trump's lie. The internal check does not verify the identity of the woman. The external check, which uses Snopes as a source, decisively contradicts the caption, scoring it as false with a confidence of 8.  Snopes explicitly states that the viral image is miscaptioned and shows Jill Harth, not E. Jean Carroll. This directly refutes the caption's central claim. The high confidence score from the external check, combined with the fact that it involves verification from a reliable source, outweighs the internal check's assessment. The internal check's confidence is largely based on an interpretation, not on factual verification of the woman's identity.  Therefore, the caption is out of context because it misidentifies the woman in the image, leading to a false conclusion. The discrepancy arises from the internal check's failure to independently verify the identity of the woman, relying instead on the caption's assertion.  The external validation, through Snopes' fact-check, provides robust evidence that the image is miscaptioned and does not support the caption's claim. The conflict highlights the importance of external validation when analyzing the veracity of captions related to potentially controversial topics. In this case, the external source provides irrefutable evidence that the caption is inaccurate.  Entity analysis would corroborate the external check, confirming the image contains Jill Harth, not E. Jean Carroll.  Based on the preponderance of evidence, particularly the high-confidence external validation from a reputable source, the caption is definitively out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal check assesses the caption as true (confidence 10) based on image content, but fails to verify the identity of the woman. External check (Snopes, confidence 8) proves the caption false by revealing the image is miscaptioned and features Jill Harth, not E. Jean Carroll. The external validation, supported by entity analysis, outweighs the internal assessment, resulting in a final verdict of 'out of context'.

results.caption: A photograph shows the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" that covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.

result.explanation: The image shows a large amount of debris in the water, but it is not clear if this is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.  The caption mentions that the garbage patch covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean; the image does not provide sufficient context to verify this claim.  Therefore, I am uncertain about the accuracy of the caption's description.  The location is mentioned as Pacific Ocean and this is visually consistent.

candidates.title: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" that covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
On 26 July 2015, the "Ripley's Believe It or Not" Facebook page shared a photograph purportedly showing the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch":
ALthough the claim associated with the photograph  that a massive garbage patch covers 8.1% of the Pacific Ocean  has been advanced by some scientists, this image does not specifically depict that particular collection of ocean-borne trash. The photograph seen here shows debris resulting from a 9.0 magnitude earthquake (and resulting tsunami) that struck northern Japan in 2011:
An aerial view of damage to Wakuya, Japan, after a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami devastated the area in northern Japan. Ships and aircraft from the Ronald Reagan Carrier Strike Group are conducting search and rescue operations and re-supply missions as directed in support of Operation Tomodachi throughout northern Japan.
Furthermore, National Geographic reported that while the name "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" may conjure up an image of a floating island of debris, the actual garbage patch itself was actually difficult to see:
For many people, the idea of a garbage patch conjures up images of an island of trash floating on the ocean. In reality, these patches are almost entirely made up of tiny bits of plastic, called microplastics. Microplastics cant always be seen by the naked eye. Even satellite imagery doesnt show a giant patch of garbage. The microplastics of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch can simply make the water look like a cloudy soup. This soup is intermixed with larger items, such as fishing gear and shoes. The seafloor beneath the Great Pacific Garbage Patch may also be an underwater trash heap. Oceanographers and ecologists recently discovered that about 70% of marine debris actually sinks to the bottom of the ocean.
The claim that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch covers "8.1 percent of the Pacific Ocean" is also a matter of debate. The number appeared to come from a 2008 quote from Marcus Eriksen, the research director at the Algalita Marine Research Foundation:
"Charles Moore, an American oceanographer who discovered the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" or "trash vortex", believes that about 100 million tons of flotsam are circulating in the region. Marcus Eriksen, a research director of the US-based Algalita Marine Research Foundation, which Mr Moore founded, said: "The original idea that people had was that it was an island of plastic garbage that you could almost walk on. It is not quite like that. It is almost like a plastic soup. It is endless for an area that is maybe twice the size as continental United States."
A 2011 study from Oregon State University, however, asserted that the real size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch was hundreds of times smaller than commonly claimed:
There is a lot of plastic trash floating in the Pacific Ocean, but claims that the "Great Garbage Patch" between California and Japan is twice the size of Texas are grossly exaggerated, according to an analysis by an Oregon State University scientist.
Further claims that the oceans are filled with more plastic than plankton, and that the patch has been growing tenfold each decade since the 1950s are equally misleading, pointed out Angelicque "Angel" White, an assistant professor of oceanography at Oregon State.
"There is no doubt that the amount of plastic in the world's oceans is troubling, but this kind of exaggeration undermines the credibility of scientists," White said. "We have data that allow us to make reasonable estimates; we dont need the hyperbole. Given the observed concentration of plastic in the North Pacific, it is simply inaccurate to state that plastic outweighs plankton, or that we have observed an exponential increase in plastic."
The studies have shown is that if you look at the actual area of the plastic itself, rather than the entire North Pacific subtropical gyre, the hypothetically "cohesive" plastic patch is actually less than 1 percent of the geographic size of Texas.
"The amount of plastic out there isn't trivial," White said. "But using the highest concentrations ever reported by scientists produces a patch that is a small fraction of the state of Texas, not twice the size."
But a study published in 2018 stated the opposite of many of these assertions -- that the Pacific Ocean trash pile was much larger than previously reported and rapidly growing, that most of its bulk was larger objects rather than microplastics, and that about one-fifth of its volume came from the 2011 Japan earthquake referenced above:
A huge, swirling pile of trash in the Pacific Ocean is growing faster than expected and is now three times the size of France.
According to a three-year study published in Scientific Reports Friday, the mass known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is about 1.6 million square kilometers in size -- up to 16 times bigger than previous estimates.
Ghost nets, or discarded fishing nets, make up almost half the 80,000 metric tons of garbage floating at sea, and researchers believe that around 20% of the total volume of trash is debris from the 2011 Japanese tsunami.
The bulk of the pile is made up of larger objects while only 8% of the mass is microplastics, or pieces smaller than 5 millimeters in size.
"We were surprised by the amount of large plastic objects we encountered," Chief Scientist Julia Reisser said in a statement.
"We used to think most of the debris consists of small fragments, but this new analysis shines a new light on the scope of the debris.
Why the discrepancy? A variety of factors made it difficult to posit an accurate estimate of the debris field's true scope in earlier surveys:
No one knows for how much debris makes up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. The North Pacific Subtropical Gyre is too large for scientists to trawl. In addition, not all trash floats on the surface. Denser debris can sink centimeters or even several meters beneath the surface, making the vortexs area nearly impossible to measure.
candidates.description: A widely circulated photograph does not show a "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" that covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.

result.explanation: The provided text contains conflicting information regarding the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. While some sources claim it covers 8.1% of the Pacific Ocean, others dispute this figure, suggesting it is significantly smaller.  The evidence does not definitively support or refute the claim in the caption, making it difficult to assess the accuracy.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 mentions conflicting claims about the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, with some sources claiming it is 8.1% of the Pacific Ocean while others claim it is much smaller.

final_result.explanation: The original caption claims the image depicts the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, stating it covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.  Internal validation expresses uncertainty, scoring a confidence of 3, because while the image shows significant debris, it lacks sufficient context to confirm it's the Great Pacific Garbage Patch or to verify its size.  External validation also scores a confidence of 3, highlighting conflicting reports on the Garbage Patch's size, some claiming 8.1%, others much less.  Neither internal nor external validation supports the caption's claim definitively.  The discrepancies lie in the inability to confirm the image's location as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch and the conflicting reports about its size.  There is no clear visual evidence to support the caption's assertion about the size of the garbage patch. The visual content is consistent with a large collection of debris, but not with the specific claim that it is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch covering over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.  Since neither validation method strongly supports the caption, and both express uncertainty, the conclusion is that the caption is out of context. candidates.title: 'Harry Potter' Author JK Rowling Reveals Daniel Radcliffe Is Chinese?
candidates.content:
Claim:
"Harry Potter" creator J.K. Rowling revealed that lead film actor Daniel Radcliffe is Chinese.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 6 January 2017, the satirical web site ClickHole, an offshoot of The Onion created to mock clickbait and viral content, posted a story reporting that the author and creator of the widely popular Harry Potter series had revealed that Daniel Radcliffe, the actor who portrayed the boy wizard in film versions of her books, is not English but Chinese:
Ever since releasing the final book in her beloved series, J.K. Rowling has been known to reveal some shocking secrets from inside the Potter universe. Whether its a characters hidden past, a plot point we may have missed, or a look inside what our favorite witches and wizards are doing today, Rowling has proven time and time again that theres still plenty we dont know about the magical world of Hogwarts. But the authors latest bombshell really takes the cake: J.K. Rowling just announced that Daniel Radcliffe is Chinese.
Whoa. Mind = blown!
As proof, the web site included a series of fake tweets by Rowling, allegedly made on 6 January 2017:
The tweets don't appear on the author's authentic Twitter timeline, and according to available biographical information, Radcliffe was born in London, and neither of his parents is of Chinese descent.
ClickHole, like its sister site The Onion, is an openly satirical web site. Here's how ClickHole describes their content on the site's "About us" page:
Lets be honest: Today, the average website carelessly churns out hundreds of pieces of pandering, misleading content, most of which tragically fall short of going viral.
At ClickHole, we refuse to stand for this. We strive to make sure that all of our content panders to and misleads our readers just enough to make it go viral. You see, we dont think anything on the internet should ever have to settle for mere tens of thousands of pageviews. We believe that each and every article  whether about pop culture, politics, internet trends, or social justice  should be clicked on and shared by hundreds of millions of internet users before they can even comprehend what they just read.
ClickHole has one and only one core belief: All web content deserves to go viral.
Some of the headlines on ClickHole's front page as of 6 January 2017 included "Passing The Torch: Watch This Father Give His Daughter His Panini Before Walking Into the Forest Forever" and "One Day I Will Understand Basketball (by Jack Nicholson)."
candidates.description: The claim that J.K. Rowling said "Harry Potter" actor Daniel Radcliffe is of Chinese heritage originated with the satirical web site ClickHole.

Rowling revealing him to be Chinese is factually incorrect and lacks visual support.  The image itself offers no indication of Radcliffe's ethnicity.  More significantly, the external check achieves a confidence score of 10, relying on a reputable source, Snopes, which definitively debunks the claim. candidates.title: No evidence Chelsea Clinton is married to George Soros nephew
candidates.content:
The Clintons and George Soros are likely bedfellows when it comes to conservative conspiracy theories, and now that union is allegedly official.
"Did you know?" begins a July 22 Facebook post with what looks like a doctored image of Chelsea Clinton and George Soros. "Chelsea Clinton is married to Mark Mezvinski (sic). Mark Mezvinski is George Soros (sic) nephew!!"
This post, which includes the words @illuminati killers, was flagged as part of Facebooks efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed. (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.)
The claim isnt a new one, and it was amplified by the actress Roseanne Barr last year when she accused Clinton of being married to Soros nephew and tweeted: "Chelsea Soros Clinton."
Clinton retweeted Barr  Barrs tweet has since been deleted  and said: "Good morning Roseanne - my given middle name is Victoria. I imagine George Soross nephews are lovely people. Im just not married to one. I am grateful for the important work @OpenSociety does in the world. Have a great day!"
Open Society Foundations is a philanthropic organization founded by Soros.
Clinton married her husband, Marc Mezvinsky, whose name was misspelled in the Facebook post, in July 2010. Reuters reported that the only high profile guests seen in the town where they married other than former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton were Madeleine Albright, who served as secretary of state under Bill Clinton, actors Ted Danson and Mary Steenburgen, and fashion designer Vera Wang.
Mezvinsky is an investment banker and the son of Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky and Edward Mezvinsky, both former Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives.
Searching the Nexis database for anything involving the couple, George Soros, and the word "nephew," we found 35 news stories. They were all about Roseanne Barrs allegation that Clinton is married to Soross nephew. And they didnt corroborate her claim.
We couldnt find any evidence to lend credence to this Facebook post. We rate it Pants on Fire!
candidates.description: The Clintons and George Soros are likely bedfellows when it comes to conservative conspiracy theories, and now that unio

result.explanation: The Politifact article directly refutes the claim that Chelsea Clinton is married to George Soros' nephew.  The article details how this false claim has spread through social media and was even tweeted by Roseanne Barr.  Chelsea Clinton herself responded to the claim on Twitter, denying it. The article concludes there is no evidence to support the claim and rates it "Pants on Fire!"
result.supporting_points:
Source 1 explicitly states: "The claim isn’t a new one, and it was amplified by the actress Roseanne Barr last year when she accused Clinton of being married to Soros’ nephew and tweeted: “Chelsea Soros Clinton.” Clinton retweeted Barr — Barr’s tweet has since been deleted — and said: “Good morning Roseanne - my given middle name is Victoria. I imagine George Soros’s nephews are lovely people. I’m just not married to one. I am grateful for the important work @OpenSociety does in the world. Have a great day!”

We couldn’t find any evidence to lend credence to this Facebook post. We rate it Pants on Fire!"

final_result.explanation: The original caption claims that Chelsea Clinton is married to George Soros' nephew.  The internal check found no evidence in the provided image to support this claim; the image only shows George Soros.  The confidence score for the internal check is 0, indicating a complete lack of supporting evidence within the image itself.  The external check, however, provides strong evidence from a Politifact article that directly refutes the claim. The Politifact article details how this false claim circulated on social media and was even tweeted by Roseanne Barr.  Chelsea Clinton herself responded on Twitter, denying the claim. The article concludes there is no evidence supporting the claim, rating it "Pants on Fire!" with a confidence score of 10.  Given the decisive evidence from the external source, contradicting the internal check's lack of evidence, we conclude the caption is entirely out of context. There is no visual evidence of Chelsea Clinton in the image and the external check confirmed the factual inaccuracy of the statement.  The high confidence score of 10 from the external check heavily outweighs the 0 confidence score of the internal check. Therefore, the final assessment is that the caption is out of context (OOC = True) with a high confidence score of 10, reflecting the strong external evidence against the caption's claim.
final_result.validation_summary: Internal check finds no evidence in the image to support the caption. External check strongly refutes the caption's claim using a Politifact article and Chelsea Clinton's own denial, resulting in a high confidence score.  Both checks align in concluding the caption is out of context.

Twitter user @buddhUU reached out to us aand noted that they had posted this message in June 2014:
The original message from @buddhUU was not attributed to Jodie Foster, either.
So this denunciation of the rich started as a generic bit that was later attached to Jodie Foster's name in order to lend it additional credence. Foster's actual views on capitalism and wealth disparity are a little more nuanced than those expressed above:

candidates.title: Did a Prague Newspaper Call U.S. a 'Confederacy of Fools' for Electing Joe Biden?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A Prague newspaper termed the American people a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Joe Biden.
Rating:
False
About this rating
Shortly after the November 2020 U.S. presidential election in which Democratic challenger Joe Biden prevailed over incumbent Donald Trump, social media users circulated a block of text -- purportedly originating with a Prague newspaper -- that termed the U.S. a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Biden:
But this item was just another piece of repurposed political misinformation, one that had previously featured Donald Trump as its subject, and Barack Obama before him. It was originally presented as a reproduction of a newspaper editorial harshly critical of those who had voted for Obama in 2008, one supposedly published in "the Prague newspaper, Prager Zeitungon." That mention appeared to be a misspelled reference to Prager Zeitung ("Prague Newspaper"), a German-language weekly newspaper from the Czech Republic which is also circulated in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. Later versions of this same item attributed that editorial to Vclav Klaus, a Czech politician who served as the first prime minister of an independent Czech Republic from 1993 to 1998 and then as the second President of the Czech Republic from 2003 to 2013.
The attributions of both publication and author were unverifiable, however. The initial version of this item (which was circulated at least as far back as April 2009) provided no contextual information such as a publication date or headline that would facilitate verification of its publication in Prager Zeitung. A search of that newspaper's website at that time pulled up only one article that mentioned Barack Obama, and that article included only an incidental reference about the level of security provided to a U.S. president. No evidence documented that this editorial had been published in either the print or online version of the Prager Zeitung.
Moreover, not only did no evidence exist showing that Vclav Klaus penned this editorial, it was exceedingly unlikely that he would have written anything like it. Vclav Klaus and Barack Obama appeared to have a reasonably good working relationship while both were in office, and Klaus had not been otherwise been recorded as writing or saying anything (in public or private) nearly so harshly critical of President Obama as the editorial attributed to him here.
Marcus Hundt, the editor-in-chief of Prager Zeitung, confirmed that the newspaper has never published such an article ... about Joe Biden nor about Barack Obama and that it primarily reports on events in the Czech Republic and Europe and not on domestic affairs in other counties.
candidates.description: Former Czech president Vclav Klaus didn't call the American people a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Joe Biden or anyone else.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes directly addresses the claim in the news caption.  Snopes explicitly states that social media users circulated a text claiming a Prague newspaper called the U.S. a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Joe Biden. Snopes then debunks this claim, stating it is false and that the text had been repurposed misinformation previously targeting other presidents.  The evidence directly supports the factual elements of the news caption.
result.supporting_points: Source 1:  "Shortly after the November 2020 U.S. presidential election in which Democratic challenger Joe Biden prevailed over incumbent Donald Trump, social media users circulated a block of text -- purportedly originating with a Prague newspaper -- that termed the U.S. a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Biden"

The external check uses Snopes as a source to corroborate the claim in the caption. Snopes directly addresses the claim that social media circulated a text— purportedly from a Prague newspaper—calling the U.S. a 'confederacy of fools' for electing Biden.  The Snopes article confirms the core elements of the caption: the circulation of the text on social media, the text's content, and the claim's association with the election of Joe Biden.  Both the internal and external checks present high confidence scores (10). The internal check's 'True' verdict, despite the visual mismatch, is supported by the external check which verifies the main claim of the caption regarding the social media circulation of the text mentioning Joe Biden. While the image itself doesn't depict the Prague newspaper or the circulated text,  the external validation makes up for this limitation, confirming the textual content of the caption through reliable source verification.  The discrepancies between internal and external checks are minor and easily explained. This discrepancy doesn't negate the fact that the caption's central claim about the online spread of text related to Joe Biden is confirmed by Snopes. candidates.title: Did 'The Simpsons' Predict Trump Would Try to Buy Greenland?
candidates.content:
Claim:
An episode of "The Simpsons" predicted that U.S. President Donald Trump would cancel his trip to Denmark after the prime minister refused to sell Greenland to the United States.
Rating:
False
About this rating
The animated show "The Simpsons" has garnered a reputation for "predicting" future events during the course of its nearly 30-year run. While a few odd coincidences exist, Simpsons prediction hoaxes may outnumber actual Simpsons predictions.
For example, "The Simpsons" did not predict that U.S. President Donald Trump would ride down an escalator while announcing his bid for president; Lady Gaga's Superbowl halftime show; the video game Pokemon Go; the fire at Notre Dame cathedral; a mass shooting during a screening of "Black Panther"; Trump's touching a glowing orb; or Trump's death.
In August 2019, after Trump mulled the idea of buying Greenland and then announced that he was canceling a trip to the area after Denmark's prime minister rejected the idea, another Simpsons "prediction" started to circulate on social media.
Sen. Chris Murphy, D-Conn., posted a message on Twitter about how the animated show had predicted the kerfuffle.
MSNBC host Rachel Maddow made a similar joke on Twitter:
While these tweets were likely posted in jest, some people didn't quite get the joke. At least two threads were started on "The Simpsons" section of Reddit asking if the prediction was real, and multiple people chimed in on Twitter about the show's uncanny ability to tell the future. Murphy's tweet was also shared on Fark as proof that "The Simpsons" creator Matt Groening had a time machine.
We searched Frinkiac, a website named after the Simpsons' bumbling mad-scientist character Professor Frink. The site allows fans to search the show's archives for favorite quotes and jokes. And nothing surfaced for mentions of the words "Greenland," "Trump," and "Denmark" together.
Furthermore, we've previously covered the show's "predictions" about Trump's presidency. And as far as we can tell, the first mention of a "President Trump" came during the season 11 episode, "Bart to the Future," in 2000. Trump was mentioned in prior seasons, but never as president or a potential buyer of Greenland:
candidates.description: The future-predicting abilities of "The Simpsons" have been exaggerated over the years.

result.explanation: The provided text explicitly states that the claim is false. Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website, investigated the claim and found no evidence in "The Simpsons" archives to support it.  Their investigation included searching Frinkiac, a database of Simpsons quotes and jokes.  The article notes that while the claim circulated on social media, it is inaccurate.
result.supporting_points:
Claim: An episode of "The Simpsons" predicted that U.S. President Donald Trump would cancel his trip to Denmark after the prime minister refused to sell Greenland to the United States. 
Rating: False
We searched Frinkiac, a website named after the Simpsons' bumbling mad-scientist character Professor Frink. The site allows fans to search the show's archives for favorite quotes and jokes. And nothing surfaced for mentions of the words "Greenland," "Trump," and "Denmark" together.

final_result.explanation: The internal consistency check reveals a significant mismatch between the image content and the caption's description. The image shows Matt Groening holding a Simpsons pillow; the caption discusses a Simpsons episode predicting a Trump-related event involving Greenland and Denmark. These are unrelated topics. The external check strongly supports the internal assessment by confirming the claim's falsity through a fact-check from a reliable source (Snopes), which further corroborates the lack of evidence supporting the caption's assertion. Both internal and external checks strongly indicate the caption's inaccuracy and its inappropriateness as a description for the given image.  The high confidence scores from both checks (0 from internal and 10 from external), despite the difference in numerical values which is likely caused by the difference in how confidence was expressed, are strongly aligned. The numerical differences can be explained by the fact that the internal check is limited by only looking at the image and caption provided, while the external check is capable of accessing and evaluating information from external sources. Thus, given the overwhelming evidence from both checks, we can conclude that the caption is entirely out of context with respect to the image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation checks strongly confirm that the caption is out of context with the provided image. The image depicts Matt Groening with a Simpsons pillow, while the caption describes a purported Simpsons prediction about Donald Trump and Greenland, which is factually incorrect according to external verification.

candidates.title: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" that covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
On 26 July 2015, the "Ripley's Believe It or Not" Facebook page shared a photograph purportedly showing the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch":
ALthough the claim associated with the photograph  that a massive garbage patch covers 8.1% of the Pacific Ocean  has been advanced by some scientists, this image does not specifically depict that particular collection of ocean-borne trash. The photograph seen here shows debris resulting from a 9.0 magnitude earthquake (and resulting tsunami) that struck northern Japan in 2011:
An aerial view of damage to Wakuya, Japan, after a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami devastated the area in northern Japan. Ships and aircraft from the Ronald Reagan Carrier Strike Group are conducting search and rescue operations and re-supply missions as directed in support of Operation Tomodachi throughout northern Japan.
Furthermore, National Geographic reported that while the name "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" may conjure up an image of a floating island of debris, the actual garbage patch itself was actually difficult to see:
For many people, the idea of a garbage patch conjures up images of an island of trash floating on the ocean. In reality, these patches are almost entirely made up of tiny bits of plastic, called microplastics. Microplastics cant always be seen by the naked eye. Even satellite imagery doesnt show a giant patch of garbage. The microplastics of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch can simply make the water look like a cloudy soup. This soup is intermixed with larger items, such as fishing gear and shoes. The seafloor beneath the Great Pacific Garbage Patch may also be an underwater trash heap. Oceanographers and ecologists recently discovered that about 70% of marine debris actually sinks to the bottom of the ocean.
The claim that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch covers "8.1 percent of the Pacific Ocean" is also a matter of debate. The number appeared to come from a 2008 quote from Marcus Eriksen, the research director at the Algalita Marine Research Foundation:
"Charles Moore, an American oceanographer who discovered the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" or "trash vortex", believes that about 100 million tons of flotsam are circulating in the region. Marcus Eriksen, a research director of the US-based Algalita Marine Research Foundation, which Mr Moore founded, said: "The original idea that people had was that it was an island of plastic garbage that you could almost walk on. It is not quite like that. It is almost like a plastic soup. It is endless for an area that is maybe twice the size as continental United States."
A 2011 study from Oregon State University, however, asserted that the real size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch was hundreds of times smaller than commonly claimed:
There is a lot of plastic trash floating in the Pacific Ocean, but claims that the "Great Garbage Patch" between California and Japan is twice the size of Texas are grossly exaggerated, according to an analysis by an Oregon State University scientist.
Further claims that the oceans are filled with more plastic than plankton, and that the patch has been growing tenfold each decade since the 1950s are equally misleading, pointed out Angelicque "Angel" White, an assistant professor of oceanography at Oregon State.
"There is no doubt that the amount of plastic in the world's oceans is troubling, but this kind of exaggeration undermines the credibility of scientists," White said. "We have data that allow us to make reasonable estimates; we dont need the hyperbole. Given the observed concentration of plastic in the North Pacific, it is simply inaccurate to state that plastic outweighs plankton, or that we have observed an exponential increase in plastic."
The studies have shown is that if you look at the actual area of the plastic itself, rather than the entire North Pacific subtropical gyre, the hypothetically "cohesive" plastic patch is actually less than 1 percent of the geographic size of Texas.
"The amount of plastic out there isn't trivial," White said. "But using the highest concentrations ever reported by scientists produces a patch that is a small fraction of the state of Texas, not twice the size."
But a study published in 2018 stated the opposite of many of these assertions -- that the Pacific Ocean trash pile was much larger than previously reported and rapidly growing, that most of its bulk was larger objects rather than microplastics, and that about one-fifth of its volume came from the 2011 Japan earthquake referenced above:
A huge, swirling pile of trash in the Pacific Ocean is growing faster than expected and is now three times the size of France.
According to a three-year study published in Scientific Reports Friday, the mass known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is about 1.6 million square kilometers in size -- up to 16 times bigger than previous estimates.
Ghost nets, or discarded fishing nets, make up almost half the 80,000 metric tons of garbage floating at sea, and researchers believe that around 20% of the total volume of trash is debris from the 2011 Japanese tsunami.
The bulk of the pile is made up of larger objects while only 8% of the mass is microplastics, or pieces smaller than 5 millimeters in size.
"We were surprised by the amount of large plastic objects we encountered," Chief Scientist Julia Reisser said in a statement.
"We used to think most of the debris consists of small fragments, but this new analysis shines a new light on the scope of the debris.
Why the discrepancy? A variety of factors made it difficult to posit an accurate estimate of the debris field's true scope in earlier surveys:
No one knows for how much debris makes up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. The North Pacific Subtropical Gyre is too large for scientists to trawl. In addition, not all trash floats on the surface. Denser debris can sink centimeters or even several meters beneath the surface, making the vortexs area nearly impossible to measure.
candidates.description: A widely circulated photograph does not show a "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" that covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.

result.explanation: Source 1 contains conflicting information regarding the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Some studies suggest it is much smaller than 8% of the Pacific Ocean, while others suggest it is larger.  The caption's claim is not definitively supported or refuted by the source.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Contains multiple studies with varying conclusions on the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.  Some studies claim much smaller sizes, while one study in 2018 claims it is significantly larger than previously thought. No single study in source 1 definitively supports or refutes the caption's 8% claim.

final_result.explanation: The original caption claims the image depicts the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, which covers over 8% of the Pacific Ocean.  Internal validation reveals a low confidence score (3) because while the image shows a significant amount of marine debris, it does not provide sufficient visual evidence to confirm this is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch or to verify the 8% coverage claim.  The scale and scope of the debris in the image are ambiguous and not comparable to the vastness implied by covering 8% of the Pacific Ocean. The entities are partially aligned. "Pacific Ocean" is vaguely related but the size claim is unsupported. External validation yields a similar low confidence score (3).  External sources present conflicting information about the Great Pacific Garbage Patch's size.  No definitive evidence supports or refutes the 8% claim. Therefore, both internal and external validation point towards the caption being inaccurate and out of context. The discrepancy between the image's local view and the caption's global claim of 8% coverage is significant. Entity analysis supports this finding by showing that while "Pacific Ocean" is present, the quantitative aspect of the claim is completely unsupported by visual evidence. The low confidence scores (3 out of 10 for both checks) are combined to form a final confidence score of 4.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation show low confidence in the caption's accuracy, primarily due to the lack of visual evidence supporting the claim that the image shows the Great Pacific Garbage Patch covering 8% of the Pacific Ocean and conflicting information about its actual size.

results.caption: NASA warned that Asteroid 52768 (1998 OR2) could hit Earth in April 2020 and cause catastrophic danger.

result.explanation: The image shows an asteroid.  The caption mentions NASA's warning about an asteroid, and the presence of an asteroid in the image is consistent with that.  Earth is mentioned in the caption but is not shown in the image.  The asteroid's name is not in the image.

candidates.title: Will an Asteroid Hit Earth in April 2020?
candidates.content:
Claim:
NASA warned that Asteroid 52768 (1998 OR2) could hit Earth in April 2020 and cause catastrophic danger.
On April 29, 2020, a large asteroid is expected to fly by earth at a distance of approximately 4 million miles. That may be of interest to stargazers, but the previous sentence isn't very alarming or attention-grabbing. Yet many media outlets wrote headlines about this incoming asteroid as if it posed an immediate and catastrophic threat to the planet.
An article in the Daily Express, for instance, was headlined: "Asteroid warning: NASA tracks a 4KM asteroid approach - Could end civilisation if it hits." The site used a similar message when promoting this article on Twitter:
While these headlines may bring clicks, they also may lead readers to falsely believe that this asteroid poses an immediate threat to life on Earth. That isn't the case.
While Asteroid 52768 (1998 OR2) will approach Earth in April 2020, the asteroid is not expected to come within 3.9 million miles of the planet.
NASA is constantly monitoring the skies for asteroids and meteors that pose a potential threat to Earth. When these near-Earth objects (NEOs) are discovered, NASA monitors them to find out when they will approach Earth, how fast they will be traveling, how large they are, and how close they will get. All of this data is publicly available on the Center for Near Earth Object Studies (CNEOS) website.
Asteroid 52768 (1998 OR2) was first discovered (as its name implies) in 1998, so this asteroid isn't making a sudden and scary appearance above Earth. NASA has been monitoring it for more than two decades and has learned quite a bit. For instance, the asteroid is relatively large with a diameter between 1.1 and 2.5 miles, and it will be traveling at just under 20,000 mph when it makes its closest approach to Earth.
While an asteroid of this size would cause catastrophic damage if it hit Earth, there's practically no chance that will happen in April 2020. According to NASA, this asteroid won't come within 3.9 million miles of Earth. In other words, it will approach no closer than about 16 times the distance between us and the moon.
CNEOS writes (emphasis ours):
On a daily basis, about one hundred tons of interplanetary material drifts down to the Earths surface. Most of the smallest interplanetary particles that reach the Earths surface are the tiny dust particles that are released by comets as their ices vaporize in the solar neighborhood. The vast majority of the larger interplanetary material that reaches the Earths surface originates as the collision fragments of asteroids that have run into one another some eons ago.
With an average interval of about 10,000 years, rocky or iron asteroids larger than about 100 meters would be expected to reach the Earths surface and cause local disasters or produce the tidal waves that can inundate low lying coastal areas. On an average of every several hundred thousand years or so, asteroids larger than a kilometer could cause global disasters. In this case, the impact debris would spread throughout the Earths atmosphere so that plant life would suffer from acid rain, partial blocking of sunlight, and from the firestorms resulting from heated impact debris raining back down upon the Earths surface. Since their orbital paths often cross that of the Earth, collisions with near-Earth objects have occurred in the past and we should remain alert to the possibility of future close Earth approaches. It seems prudent to mount efforts to discover and study these objects, to characterize their sizes, compositions and structures and to keep an eye upon their future trajectories.
[...]
No one should be overly concerned about an Earth impact of an asteroid or comet. The threat to any one person from auto accidents, disease, other natural disasters and a variety of other problems is much higher than the threat from NEOs. Over long periods of time, however, the chances of the Earth being impacted are not negligible so that some form of NEO insurance is warranted. At the moment, our best insurance rests with the NEO scientists and their efforts to first find these objects and then track their motions into the future. We need to first find them, then keep an eye on them.
candidates.description: Clickbait headlines continue to stoke fears about "doomsday asteroids."

result.explanation: The news caption states that NASA warned about asteroid 52768 hitting Earth in April 2020 and causing catastrophic damage. candidates.title: Did Jodie Foster Say 'Attacking the Rich Is Self-Defense'?
candidates.content:
Claim:
Actress Jodie Foster said that attacking the rich is not envy, it's self-defense.
Rating:
False
About this rating
An image featuring a picture of actress Jodie Foster alongside a quote ostensibly uttered by her about wealth disparity in the United States being the cause of poverty is frequently circulated on social media:
Attacking the rich is not envy. It is self defense. The hoarding of wealth is the cause of poverty. The rich aren't just indifferent to poverty; they create it and maintain it.
This quote did not originate with Jodie Foster, however.
One of the earliest version of this statement we've found so far was posted in February 2016 to the TJshome.com website in the "Funny Status Message" section. Twitter user @buddhUU reached out to us aand noted that they had posted this message in June 2014:
The original message from @buddhUU was not attributed to Jodie Foster, either.
So this denunciation of the rich started as a generic bit that was later attached to Jodie Foster's name in order to lend it additional credence. Foster's actual views on capitalism and wealth disparity are a little more nuanced than those expressed above:

candidates.title: Is Anderson Cooper Laughing at Kellyanne Conway?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows Anderson Cooper laughing uncontrollably after Kellyanne Conway used the phrase "alternative facts."
In January 2017, a video was posted to YouTube purportedly showing CNN host Anderson Cooper laughing uncontrollably at Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway after the latter used the phrase "alternative facts" during an interview to explain the discrepancies between claimed attendance figures for President Trump's inauguration:
Although the footage of Cooper laughing is real, it was not related to Conway's "alternative facts" comment (as should be evident from the multiple obvious cuts and repetitions in the clip).
This video was compiled using footage showing Cooper getting the giggles during a 2011 episode of AC360, as the host was reporting on a story about French actor Gerard Depardieu's urinating on a plane:
The clip of Conway using the term "alternative facts" is also real, although she didn't utter this phrase during an interview with Cooper. The Conway clip was gleaned from a 22 January 2017 Meet the Press interview with Chuck Todd. While Todd was taken aback by Conway's comment, his reaction to it was not to succumb to an uncontrollable fit of the giggles:
CHUCK TODD: (...) answer the question of why the president asked the White House press secretary to come out in front of the podium for the first time and utter a falsehood? Why did he do that? It undermines the credibility of the entire White House press office ...
KELLYANNE CONWAY: No it doesn't.
CHUCK TODD: ... on day one.
KELLYANNE CONWAY: Don't be so overly dramatic about it, Chuck. What ... you're saying it's a falsehood. And they're giving Sean Spicer, our press secretary, gave alternative facts to that. But the point remains ...
CHUCK TODD: Wait a minute. Alternative facts?
KELLYANNE CONWAY: ... that theres ...
CHUCK TODD: Alternative facts? Four of the five facts he uttered, the one thing he got right ...
KELLYANNE CONWAY: ... hey, Chuck, why ... Hey Chuck ...
CHUCK TODD: ... was Zeke Miller. Four of the five facts he uttered were just not true. Look, alternative facts are not facts. They're falsehoods.
Sources
Sinderbrand, Rebecca. "How Kellyanne Conway ushered in the era of alternative facts." Washington Post. 22 January 2017.
Dan Evon is a former writer for Snopes.
candidates.description: A video showing CNN host Anderson Cooper laughing uncontrollably at Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway is a spoof.

result.explanation: The provided text explicitly states that a video showing Anderson Cooper laughing uncontrollably after Kellyanne Conway's use of "alternative facts" is a spoof.  The video is a compilation of unrelated footage.  The evidence directly refutes the claim in the news caption.

candidates.title: Did Marla Maples Die in a Plane Crash?
candidates.content:
Claim:
President Trump's second wife, Marla Maples, died in a plane crash in April 2017.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 17 April 2017, fake news site True Trumpers published a page containing only the clickbait headline "Just In: Trumps Ex-Wife Marla Maples Died After Airline Accident!" and a photograph of what appeared to be the wreckage of a crashed plane:
There is no truth to the sensational headline, a claim which would have made worldwide news if it were accurate; indeed, the image used here is actually from July 1997, when a Federal Express plane crashed and burned during a landing at Newark International Airport. (Despite the dramatic image, only minor injuries were reported.)

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external checks strongly indicate that the original caption is out of context. The internal check has a confidence score of 0 and correctly identifies that the image depicts Marla Maples, but the caption falsely claims she died in a plane crash in April 2017.  This is further corroborated by the external check which provides a confidence score of 10, citing Snopes, a reputable fact-checking website. Snopes explicitly debunks this claim, confirming that Marla Maples is still alive and that the claim originated from fake news sources which misused an unrelated image from a 1997 plane crash.  There is no conflict between the internal and external assessments; both point to the caption being factually incorrect and out of context. The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong evidence from both the internal analysis and the external verification through Snopes.  The image is clearly of Marla Maples, and widely available information confirms she is alive, directly contradicting the caption's assertion.  There is no ambiguity or uncertainty in this case. The evidence consistently shows that the caption is entirely false and unrelated to the image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation methods strongly support that the caption is out of context. The internal analysis identifies the image subject correctly but refutes the caption's false death claim.  External verification using Snopes provides definitive proof of the claim's falsity.
